issues.title: Missing Service Animal Legal Requirements and Definitions
issues.description: The policy mentions "seeing-eye dogs and service dogs" but fails to comply with current ADA definitions and requirements. California law requires districts to follow federal ADA requirements which define service animals specifically as dogs (and in limited cases miniature horses) trained to perform specific tasks for individuals with disabilities. The policy uses outdated terminology and lacks proper legal framework.

legal_citations.text: School districts must comply with federal civil rights laws including the Americans with Disabilities Act

issues.required_language: Service animals are defined as dogs that are individually trained to do work or perform tasks for people with disabilities. Service animals are working animals, not pets. The work or task a dog has been trained to provide must be directly related to the person's disability. The district shall allow service animals to accompany students and staff with disabilities in all areas where the public is normally allowed to go.

issues.title: Missing Emotional Support Animal Distinction
issues.description: The policy fails to distinguish between service animals and emotional support animals, which have different legal protections and requirements under federal law. This creates potential compliance issues and confusion.

legal_citations.text: Districts must comply with Section 504 and ADA requirements regarding assistance animals

issues.required_language: Emotional support animals, comfort animals, and therapy dogs are not service animals under the ADA. These animals may be considered as reasonable accommodations under Section 504 on a case-by-case basis through the IEP or 504 plan process.

issues.title: Missing Health Department Notification Requirements
issues.description: California requires school districts to coordinate with local health departments regarding animals on campus, particularly for ongoing animal presence and potential disease exposure incidents.

legal_citations.text: School districts shall cooperate with local health departments in matters affecting student health and safety

issues.required_language: The district shall notify the local health department of any animal bite incidents or suspected animal-related disease exposure. For animals remaining on campus longer than one day, the principal shall notify the local health department and maintain records of animal health documentation.

issues.title: Missing Prohibited Animals List and Safety Requirements
issues.description: The regulation mentions "poisonous or wild animals" but lacks a comprehensive prohibited animals list and specific safety protocols required by California health and safety codes.

legal_citations.text: Schools must maintain safe environments and prevent exposure to dangerous animals and zoonotic diseases

issues.required_language: Prohibited animals include but are not limited to: venomous animals, wild or exotic animals, primates, reptiles, amphibians, birds of prey, and any animal prohibited by local health department regulations. All animal activities must include hand-washing facilities and protocols.

issues.title: Outdated Last Review Date
issues.description: The policy and regulation were last reviewed in 2010, which predates significant changes in ADA service animal regulations (2011) and other legal developments. Regular review ensures compliance with current law.

legal_citations.text: School boards shall regularly review and update policies to ensure legal compliance

issues.required_language: This policy should be reviewed and updated to reflect current legal requirements, particularly ADA service animal regulations effective 2011.
